newsitem.title: USA: Enron seen offering Ore. more rate savings.
newsitem.headline: Enron seen offering Ore. more rate savings.

text.p: Enron Corp at a settlement meeeting on Tuesday is expected to offer customers of Portland General Electric Co at least $5 million a year in rate savings for four years following the companies' merger, industry sources said Monday.
The merger partners submitted on Friday a revised plan to the Oregon Public Utilities Commission (OPUC).
Sources close to the negotiations, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the new plan expands the companies' earlier estimate of $3 million in annual merger-related savings.
Tom Riordan, an OPUC analyst, said the new proposal includes "variations" on the rate cut plan as well as "a number of conditions and contingencies."
The staff of the OPUC earlier approved the merger, but with conditions including a $47.4 million annual rate cut for four years after the merger.
The three-member OPUC has said Enron would have to come up from the $3 million figure in order to gain final merger approval from the state.
The latest proposal also calls for customers to split with shareholders some of the merger-related savings above $5 million, the sources said.
Enron reportedly said the companies would have an economic incentive, but not an obligation to achieve a target savings level of $9 million a year.
Officials at the OPUC as well as Enron and Portland General would not comment on the specifics of the proposal until after Tuesday's settlement meeting.
